lg.l: AGeynF.12.1: The ornamental capital is blue with red and green flourishes in the left margin the length of the page. The scribe's guide <a> for the rubricator is visible in the middle of the rubricated letter. y gan to sleepe softe / & my syÈde y gan to turne. These two lines appear only in F.
& a-noon y seyÈ . as y seyÈ erst / & spak to hym with mowÃ¾e.

For haukyne love Ã¾e actif man / euere y shal Èow lovie.
But Èit y am in a weer / what charite ys to meene.

& so Ã¾orghÈ god & goodemen / groweth frut of Charite.
I wolde trauayleF.12.12: An otiose curl is written above the <y>. Ã¾is tre to seen / quod y ï ¡ .xx.ti hundred myle.
To have my fille of Ã¾at frut / & for-sake al oÃ¾ir sawle

/[Â¶] It groweth in a gardyn quod he / Ã¾at god made hym-seluen.
A-myddis mannys body / Ã¾e more is of Ã¾at stokke.
Herte . hatte Ã¾at herber / Ã¾at Ã¾e tree in groweth.F.12.17: F's reading is unique. Bx has "Ã¾at it Inne groweÃ¾."
And liberum arbitrium . haÃ¾ Ã¾e Lond to feerme.
& vndir isF.12.19: Alpha is responsible for the intrusion of And, but F alone reverses the hierarchy by adding is. pers Ã¾e plowhman / to pyken it & weden it.
Peers Ã¾e Plowhman quod y Ã¾o ï ¡ & al for pure IoyÈe.
Ãat y herde nempne his name / a-non y swowned after.
& longe lay in a love-dreem / & at Ã¾e laste me Ã¾owhte.
Ãat Peers Ã¾e Plowhman anon / al Ã¾e place me schewede.
& bad me tooten on Ã¾e tre / on top / & on roote.
& with Ã¾re pyleris it was vndir-pyght /. y parceyved it sone.
Â¶ Peers quod y / y praye Ã¾e / why stonden Ã¾ese pileris heere.

/ [Â¶] For wyndys / wilt Ã¾ou wete quod hee ï ¡ to kepeF.12.27: Alpha is responsible for kepe. Beta witnesses have witen. it fram fallyng.F.12.27: F omits the following line: "Cum ceciderit iustus non collidetur quia dominus supponit manum suam."
In blomynge tyme a-bide no floures / but Ã¾ese pileris helpen.

Ãe world is a wikkid wynd / & wendeth a-mong Ã¾e levis.F.12.29: Eye-skip caused alpha to omit the b-verse and following a-verse. Interestingly, a drypoint <x> appears in the right margin at this point, suggesting awareness of text outside alpha. Bx reads as follows:
The world is a wikked wynd to hem Ã¾at willen truÃ¾e
Coueitise comÃ¾ of Ã¾at wynd and crepeÃ¾ among Ã¾e leues.
& for-fret neyÈ Ã¾e frut / Ã¾orgh fele fayre syghtes.
Ãe fyrste pyler y calle / ys Potencia deiF.12.31: F's reading is unique. Bx has "Thanne with Ã¾e first pil I palle him doun Ã¾at is potencia dei patris."
Â¶ Ãe fleschÈ is a fel wynd / Ã¾at fleeÃ¾ in flourynge tyme.
Ãorgh lykynge Ã¾orghÈ lustis / so lowde he gynneÃ¾ blowe.
Ãat it norscheÃ¾ nyce syghtes / & sum-tyme nyse woordys.
& Ã¾er-of comen wykkede werkis / & wormes of synne.F.12.35: A black <x> appears in the right margin.
& for-byteÃ¾ Ã¾e blosmes / ryght to Ã¾e bare leevis.

Ãat is passioun[Ã¾e] passioun & Ã¾e powher / of oure prince Iesu

With prayeris & penauncesF.12.39: F's a-verse is unique. Beta witnesses have "ThoruÈ preieres and Ã¾oruÈ penaunces." Alpha is responsible for "With" in place of the first "ThoruÈ," but R has the second. / & cristis passioun in myÈnde.

& foondiÃ¾ Ã¾e feend / my frut to distroye.
With alle wyÈles Ã¾at he can / he waggeÃ¾ Ã¾e roote.

Bakbyteris & boosteris / & blawrerisb[r]aw[l]eris & chyderys /
He heHe leyÃ¾ a laddir Ã¾erto / of lesyngys are Ã¾e rybbis.

He feccheÃ¾ a-weyÈ myn floures / by-fore boÃ¾e myn eyÈen.

hi.hi: Videatis ï ¡ qui peccat in spiritum sanctum . numquam.

l.note: F.12.50: Beta manuscripts have remittetur after numquam, probably because of a defective exemplar. R has re &c.

hi.hi: Hoc est idem qui peccat per liberum arbitrium non repugnat

Ãey manace by-hyÈnde me / myn frut for to fecche.

& puttyÃ¾ a-doun Ã¾e powke / priuylyF.12.55: Alpha is responsible for priuyly. Beta witnesses have pureliche. Ã¾orghÈ grace.
& with helpe of Ã¾e holy goost / & Ã¾us have y Ã¾e maystrie.
Â¶ Now fayre falle Èee pers / quod y ï ¡ so fayre Èe discriuen.
Ãe powher of Ã¾ese postes / & here propre myghtes.
But y have Ã¾oght a Ã¾rowe / of Ã¾ese Ã¾re pyleris.
In what woode Ã¾ey woxen / & were Ã¾at Ã¾ey grewen.
For alle are Ã¾ey a-lyche long / non lasse Ã¾an oÃ¾ir.
& to my meende as me Ã¾ynkeÃ¾ / in oon moor Ã¾ey grewe
& al of oon gretnesse / & greene of greyn Ã¾ey semen.
Â¶ Ãat is sooÃ¾ seyde Pers / it may so by-fallyn.
I shal tellyn Ã¾e as tyÈt / what Ã¾is tree hette.
Ãe grownde Ã¾ere it groweth on / goodnesse men it calle.
& y tolde Ã¾e erst what hyÈte Ã¾e tre / Ã¾e trinnyte it meeneÃ¾.
Â¶ & Ã¾anne egrily he lokede on me / & Ã¾erfore y sparede /
To aske hym ony moore Ã¾ere-of / but preyede hym ful fayre.
To discrive me Ã¾e frut / Ã¾at so fayre hangede.
Â¶ Heere now be-neÃ¾e quod he Ã¾o / yf y neede hadde.
Matrimonye y may neme / a moyst frut with-alle.
Ãan contynence is neer Ã¾e croop / as caylewey bastard.
Ãan beryÃ¾ Ã¾e croop kendest frut / & klennest of alle.
Maydenhod angelys perys / & Ã¾o raÃ¾est wil be rype.
& sweete with-oute swellyng / sorwe worÃ¾ it euere.
Â¶ I prayede Peers / to pullyn doun / an appil if he wolde.F.12.77: Roman numeral xj is written (erroneously) in a lighter brown ink in the right margin.
& suffre me to a-saye / what savour it hadde.
& Peers caste to Ã¾e croop / & Ã¾an comsed it to criÈen.

& a-noon waggede wedewhod / & sore wepteF.12.80: The scribe initially wrote a long which he converted to make a

. after.
& whan he mevede Matrimonye / it made a myche noyse
Ãan had y rewÃ¾e / whan peers ruschedF.12.82: Alpha is probably responsible for rusched. R has rused, while beta witnesses have rogged. / it gradde so rewfully.
For euere as Ã¾ey droppid a-doun / Ã¾e deuyl was Ã¾ere redy.
& gadrede hem alle to-gydres / boÃ¾e greete & smale.
BoÃ¾e Adam & habraham / & ysaye Ã¾e prophete.
& sampson & samewel / & seynt Iohan Ã¾e baptist.
& bar hem forÃ¾ boldly / no-body wolde hym lette.
& made of holy men his hoord / in lymbo inferni.
Ãere is derknesse & dreede / & Ã¾e deuyl mayster.
Â¶ & Peers for pure teene / Ã¾o oo pyler he lawhte.
& hitte after hym / happe how it myghte.
Filius be Ã¾e fadres wille / & frenesse of spiritus sancti.
To goo robbe Ã¾at ragman / & be-reve Ã¾e frut fram his place.

Â¶ Ãane spak spiritus sanctus / in gabriellisF.12.94: The barred double <l> is ambiguous, usually standing for <-e>, but sometimes unmistakably representing <-is> or <-es>. MS R alone among the remaining B manuscripts lacks the genitive inflection, so the ambiguity is nearly complete. mowthe.
To a maide Ã¾at hyÈte Marie / a meeke Ã¾yng withalle.
Ãat oon / a Iustises sone / muste Iowken in hire chambre.
Tyl Plenitudo temporis / tyme come it were.
Ãat Peersis frut flowrede / & fel whan it was rype.
& Ã¾an shulde Iesu Iustne Ã¾erfore / by Iugement of armes.
WheyÃ¾ir sholde fonge Ã¾e frut / Ã¾e feend or hym-selue.
Â¶ Ãe Maide myÈldely Ã¾o / Ã¾e messager she grauntyd.F.12.101: The scribe marks the last two words for separation with a tick above and below the line.
& seyde hendely to hym / loo me his hand-mayde.
For to worchen his wille / with-outyn ony synne.

hi.hi: Ecce ancilla domini . fiat michi secundum verbum tuuntuu[m].

lg.l: & in Ã¾e wombe of Ã¾at wenche / was he .xl. wykys.
Tyl he wex aF.12.106: The graph actually looks more like the scribe's <&> than capital <A>. fawnt Ã¾orgh hire flesch / & on fytÈfy[Èt] he coude.
To have y-fowte with Ã¾e fend / er ful tyme come.
& Peers y parseyuede / in Ã¾at plener tyme.
& lerned hym lechecraft / his lyf for to saven.
Ãat Ã¾owh he were of his enemy hurt / to warsche hym sone.
& dide hym a-saye surgerie / on hem Ã¾at syke weren.
Tyl he was parfyÈt practysour / if ony pereylis fellen.
& sowhte owt Ã¾e syke / & Ã¾e synful boÃ¾e.
He saluedF.12.114: An otiose curl appears above the <d>. Ã¾e syke & synful / boÃ¾e blynde & krokede.
& comoun wymmen he conuertyde / & to crist turned hem.

hi.hi: Non est sanis opus medicus . sed male habentibus.

lg.l: Â¶ BoÃ¾e Meselis & mysseses / Ã¾at of Ã¾e menysoun weren.

Ofte he helede swiche / he hild it lytil maystrie. F has revised the syntax of Bx which reads as follows:
Ofte he heeled swiche he held it for no maistrie
Saue Ã¾o he leched lazar Ã¾at hadde yleye in graue
Quatriduanus quelt quyk dide hym walke.
Save Ã¾o / he lechide lazar / Ã¾at hadde y-leyn in grave.
Qvatriduanus boÃ¾e quert / & quik he dyde hym ryse.
Â¶ But as he made Ã¾at maistrie / mestus cepit esse
& wepte water with hise eyÈes / Ã¾ere seyÈen it manye.
& summe Ã¾at Ã¾e syghte seyÈe / seyden in Ã¾at tyme.
Ãat he was a leche of lyf / & lord of hyÈe heuene.

Â¶ Ãe Iewis Ianglyd Ã¾ere a-geyn / Ã¾o Ã¾at Iugged Ã¾e lawes.F.12.125: F's b-verse is unique. Most beta manuscripts read "and Iuggede lawes." Alpha is responsible for F's Ã¾at, but F uniquely has Ã¾o and Ã¾e.
& seyde he wroghte Ã¾orgh wicche-craft / & with Ã¾e deuelis myght
Demonium habes / Ã¾e domes-men seyden.F.12.127: F is unique in having a b-verse.
Â¶ Ãan are Èee cherlys quod crist / & Èoure childryn boÃ¾e.
& sathan Èoure saviour / Èoure-selue may witnesse.
For y have salued Èoure-selue / & Èoure sones after.
Èoure bodies & Èoure beestis / & blynde men y holpe.
& fed Èow with two fyschis / & with fyve lovis.
& left basketys of broke mete / bere a-wey who wolde.
He mysseyde Ã¾e Iewis manly Ã¾us / & manassid hem to beete.
& knokkid on hem with a corde / & caste doun here stallys.
Ãat in chirche chaffaredyn / er changid ony monee.
& seyde Ã¾us in syght of hem alle / so Ã¾at alle it herde.
I shal ouer-terve Ã¾is temple / & a-doun it Ã¾rowe.
& in Ã¾re dayes after / edyfye it newe.
& make it as myche . or moore / in alle manere poyntis.
As euere it was . & as wyÈd / wherfore y hote Èow heere.
Of prayerys & of parfyÈtnesse / Ã¾is place Èee callyn after.
Â¶ BoÃ¾e Envie & evil wyl / was a-mong Ã¾e Iewis.
Ãey casten & contriueden / to kylle hym whan Ã¾ey myghte.
Ech day after oÃ¾ir / here tyme Ã¾ey Ã¾an waytyd.
Â¶ Tyl it be-fel on a fryday / by-fore pask a lytel.
On Ã¾ursday by-fore Ã¾at / Ã¾an he made his cene.
& syttende at Ã¾at soper / hym-selue seyde Ã¾ese wordis.
I am sold / Ã¾orgh summe of Èow / he shal Ã¾at tyme rewe.
Ãat euere he solde his sauyour / for siluerene plates.
Â¶ Iudas Iangelede Ã¾ere a-geyn / & Ientil Iesu hym toolde.
It was hym-selue soÃ¾ly / & seyde tu dicis.
Ãan wente forÃ¾ / Ã¾at wikkid man / & with Ã¾e Iewis he mette.
& tolde hem be what tokne / Ã¾ey sholde knowe his mayster.

Ãat kyssyngge with fair contynaunce / & with vnkyÈnde wille.
& so was with Iudas Ã¾oo / Ã¾at Iesus by-trayede.
Ave rabbi / quod Ã¾at rybawde / & ryght to hym he wente.
& kest hym to by cawht Ã¾er-by / & kyllyd Ã¾orghÈF.12.160: Alpha has Ã¾orghÈ. Beta witnesses have of. Ã¾e Iewis.
Â¶ Ãanne Iesu to Iudas / & to alle Ã¾e Iewis seyde.
Falsnesse y fyÈnde / in Ã¾yn false speche.
& gyle in Ã¾y glad cheere / & galle is in Ã¾yn lawhyng.
Ãou shaltshalt [be] merour after / to manye men to disseyve.
But Ã¾e woors & Ã¾e wikkidnesse / shal worthe on Ã¾y-selue.
Necesse est vt veniat Scandalum.F.12.166: F's veniat Scandalum is unique. Bx has veniant scandala.

hi.hi: Ve homini illi per quem scandalum venit.

InF.12.170: Alpha has In. Beta witnesses have On. a Ã¾ursday in Ã¾erknesseF.12.170: The reading Ã¾erknesse occurs only in F. R joins most beta manuscripts in reading Ã¾esternesse, both words meaning "darkness." / Ã¾us was y[he] taken.

He Iustnede in Ierusalem / gret Ioye to vs alle.
& on a cros on Caluerye / crist took Ã¾e batayle.

Ayeins deeÃ¾ and Ã¾e deuel destruyed hir boÃ¾eres myÈtes
